section: Section 4: Units and Measurements - MCQ Breakdown

questions.text: Farad per meter is the unit of:
questions.solution: Farad per meter is the unit of permittivity. Electric conductance is measured in Siemen (s), and Permeability is measured in Henry/meter.

questions.text: Henry per meter is the unit of:
questions.solution: Henry per meter is the unit of permeability. This is a fundamental electromagnetic unit in the SI system.

questions.text: Heat supplied to a system is measured in:
questions.solution: Heat supplied to a system is measured in Joule or Calorie. 1 Calorie = 4.18 Joule.

questions.text: Which instrument is used for the measurement of heat?
questions.solution: Calorimeter is used to measure the thermal change. Ammeter measures current, Wattmeter measures power, Energy meter measures total power.

questions.text: When you convert one inch from British to SI unit, it becomes:
questions.solution: One inch from British to SI unit is equal to 2.54 cm. This is a standard conversion factor.

questions.text: The SI unit for electrical resistivity is:
questions.solution: SI unit of electrical resistivity is ohm meter. Electric field strength is Volt/meter, Magnetic field strength is Tesla or Ampere/meter.

questions.text: What is the S.I unit of potential difference?
questions.solution: SI Unit: Electric charge - Coulomb, Electric field - Tesla, Potential difference - Volt, Electric current - Ampere.

questions.text: Generally, the capacity of a battery is expressed in:
questions.solution: An ampere hour is a unit in which capacity of battery can be expressed. 1 Ampere - hour is equal to 3600 Coulombs. It is a useful metric to determine the capacity of an energy storage device.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a derived unit?
questions.solution: Derived unit: Those units of physical quantities which are derived from units of fundamental quantities are called derived units. Mol is a fundamental unit.

questions.text: Which of the following is a base unit?
questions.solution: Candela is base unit. Hence option (a) is correct.

questions.text: Katal is the unit of:
questions.solution: Katal is the unit of catalytic activity. It is equivalent to 1 mole/second.

questions.text: Which of the following option does not have SI unit?
questions.solution: Frequency does not have SI base unit. The SI unit of frequency is hertz which is the reciprocal of time period.

questions.text: One mile is approximately equivalent to _____ kilometers.
questions.solution: 1 mile = 1.69344 Kilometers. Hence, option (d) is correct.

questions.text: The SI unit of momentum is:
questions.solution: Momentum - It is the product of the mass and velocity of the object whose change against time gives force. p = m×v. Where, F = momentum, m = mass of object, v = velocity.
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 21.01.2019 Shift I

questions.text: Which of the following has no unit?
questions.solution: Relative density - It is defined as the ratio of density of a substance with respect to the density of water. It is dimensionless quantity denoted by R.D.
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 21.01.2019 Shift I

questions.text: Which one of the following physical quantities is a vector quantity?
questions.solution: Dipole moment - The product of the charge and the distance between the two charges is called dipole moment. It is a vector quantity.
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 21.01.2019 Shift I

questions.text: Which of the following is not a vector quantity?
questions.solution: Vector Quantity - A physical quantity which has both magnitude and direction. Displacement, velocity, acceleration, momentum, force, weight are examples of vector quantity. Scalar quantity - A scalar quantity only has a magnitude. Some common examples of scalar quantity are mass, speed, volume, temperature, density etc.
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 21.01.2019 Shift I

questions.text: The dimensional formula of speed is:
questions.solution: The dimensional formula of speed is [LT⁻¹]. Where, L = Length, T = Time.
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 21.01.2019 Shift II

questions.text: Light year is the unit of:
questions.solution: Light year is a unit of length. It is used to express Astronomical distances. 1 L.Y. = Speed of light × 1 year = 3×10⁸ × (365×24×3600) = 9.46×10¹⁵ km = 5.88 trillion miles (5.88×10¹² miles).
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 21.01.2019 Shift II

questions.text: The distance covered by light in one year is called:
questions.solution: The distance travelled by light in one year is called metric light year. It is the unit of astronomical distance.
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 22.01.2019 Shift II

questions.text: The distance covered by a particle in time T is given by s = at+bt² where 'a' and 'b' are constants. The dimensional formula of 'b' is:
questions.solution: Given: S = at+bt². From the principle of dimensional homogeneity, the L.H.S. of the equation must be dimensionally equal to the R.H.S. So, the dimension of (a), (at) and (bt²) is same. Dimension of distance (s) = [L]. The dimensional formula of b is [LT⁻²].
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 22.01.2019 Shift II

questions.text: S.I. Unit of universal gravitational constant is:
questions.solution: G = F×r²/(m₁×m₂). Unit of universal law for gravitation, G = N×m²/kg² = Nm²kg⁻².
questions.pyq_year: RRB ALP CBT II Physics & Maths 22.01.2019 Shift II

questions.text: One nanometer is equal to centimeter (cm):
questions.solution: One nanometer is equal to centimeter (cm) = 10⁻⁷ cm.

questions.text: The number of base unit in the S.I. system is:
questions.solution: The number of base unit in the S.I. system is 7 (seven). These are: meter, kilogram, second, ampere, kelvin, mole, candela.

questions.text: One angstrom is equal to:
questions.solution: One angstrom is equal to 10⁻¹⁰ meter. It is commonly used to measure atomic and molecular dimensions.

questions.text: The minimum reading marked on the scale is called:
questions.solution: The minimum reading marked on the scale is called Actual value. Least count is the smallest measurement that can be made with an instrument.

questions.text: How many millimeters (mm) are in one micron:
questions.solution: How many millimeters (mm) are in one micron = 10⁻³ mm. Since 1 micron = 10⁻⁶ m and 1 mm = 10⁻³ m.

questions.text: If the errors in a measuring instrument are less than its accuracy, it will be affected:
questions.solution: If the errors in a measuring instrument are less than its accuracy, it will not affect the accuracy. The accuracy of a measuring instrument is related to Accuracy ∝ 1/error.

questions.text: Electric current is measured by:
questions.solution: Electric current is measured by Ammeter. The unit of current is ampere.

questions.text: The time taken by the earth to revolve around the sun is of the order of:
questions.solution: The time taken by the earth to revolve around the sun is of the order of 10⁷ second. One year ≈ 365 × 24 × 3600 ≈ 3.15 × 10⁷ seconds.
